awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Spectral Functional Principal Components on Abelian Groups with Applications to Spatial Functional Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Massive data sets on gridded 2D and 3D domains have recently become available through computer climate model outputs, records from satellite remote sensing and brain scans, among others. These data sets have both temporal and spatial dimension. For example, a state of vegetation is observed on a grid covering an agricultural area at regular time intervals, every day or every week.  Such data can be viewed as functions of time, one function per spatial grid unit. Their chief characteristic is the spatial dependence of curves observed at the grid nodes. There is an increasing need to develop statistical tools, which will allow researchers to extract useful information from such data. The PIs will develop such tools.  The data and problems that motivate this research arise in several science fields, which have important impacts on society. For example, conclusions drawn from future climate models help the government and corporations plan for the allocation of various assets. Brain research on trauma experienced by military veterans and on Alzheimer's disease are recognized as important societal goals. The statistical research the PIs will conduct will provide useful quantitative tools to help scientists in these fields. Mathematical foundations of the new approach will be created, together with domain-specific approaches. The new methods will be implemented in R packages and made available to research community, government agencies and commercial enterprises. In the course of the proposed research, two Ph.D. students will be trained. 

The PIs will create a new framework for inference for functional data defined on domains with an additive group structure. The new dimension reduction approach will have characteristics of a multi-scale, data-driven representation, which takes into account the dependence of the functions defined on group elements, for example spatial grid nodes. The PIs will use methods of Fourier analysis on Abelian groups, spectral theory for functional data, invariance principles in Hilbert spaces, computationally efficient spatio-temporal spline representations, routines for downloading and manipulating massive data sets. The PIs will develop several inferential procedures, including bootstrap-based inference, tests for the spatial and distributional structure, and applications to the evaluation of the accuracy of computer climate models. The PIs will also develop corresponding computational techniques, which will lead to the computationally fast representation of various data structures of large to massive size.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have developed new mathematical tools and software related to the analysis of data that can be represented as curves that change through time or surfaces that move over space and time, particularly when the data are observed on a regular grid. We have created new mathematical tools that can take very large data sets that are not on a grid and predict the values on a grid of locations. The data can also be represented in a special way that enhances our ability to describe how the data changes over space and time. The special representation comes with the added benefit of being able to store the data more compactly (e.g., the special representation requires only 1% of the disk storage required by the raw data). Most importantly, these methods are specifically designed to handle massive amounts of spatio-temporal data that traditional mathematical tools cannot be used for. One of the tools incorporates a natural mechanism for describing how the similarity of the data can change over time, such as how temperatures tend to fluctuate more rapidly and across a wider range of values during the winter season compared to the summer season.

We also developed a flexible mathematical tool that allows researchers to assess whether the typical behavior of two sets of surfaces moving over space and time are similar, but if not, where, when, and how they differ. In particular, our tool is well-suited to comparing the behavior of observed climate data to data produced by state-of-the-art climate models. This comparison is challenging because even though the data sets can be massive in terms of the number of locations and times observed, there are relatively few observations with which to describe “typical” behavior. Our tool requires only minimal and realistic assumptions about the data but allows us to create new data sets from the existing data that allow us to better describe typical behavior. Perhaps more importantly, our tool is highly flexible with respect to the kinds of typical behavior that can be compared. We can describe typical behavior with characteristics such as averages, variance, or more exotic and precise characteristics. Our tool naturally adapts to increasingly large data sets using high performance computing, which will allow it to be applied to even larger, more complex future data sets. We applied our tool to state-of-the-art data climate model data from the North American Coordinated Regional Climate Downscaling Experiment (NA-CORDEX) and 5th generation reanalysis data from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ERA5), gleaning new insights into how similar they are.

We created several new tools for detecting clusters of disease in space and time. We also performed a comprehensive study comparing the performance of previously available cluster detection tools in correctly identifying clusters of many different shapes and other characteristics. Our new tools can be used to detect clusters of many different shapes in a relatively short amount of time; they can help confirm patterns discovered by other methods while also identifying new areas of disease outbreak. We have applied these tools in the detection of clusters of foodborne illnesses, breast cancer cases, and devastating respiratory disease.

We have increased the impact of our work by making software available that makes the tools we have developed available to others. The software is free, easy to access, and includes documentation that will help others to use the software. The software we have provided has already been downloaded thousands of times.

We have provided training to several future scientists, some of whom have already embarked on their future careers in industry and academia, with interests spanning public health, the environment, and economics. These scientists have been trained in identifying relevant problems, pursuing a solution, writing their results, and creating software for others to utilize the tools they have created.

Our research has the potential to be highly impactful in climate science with respect to future policymaking. Already, our research has been applied in assessing how well the state-of-the-art climate models are in capturing historical climate behavior and in identifying ways in which the patterns do not match. Our tools have been packaged so that other researchers can continue investigate this relationship so that climate models can continue to mature. What is learned from this process can be used in advising our policymakers on how to best prepare and respond to potential climate change.

The accurate and timely detection of disease clusters plays a crucial role in public health decisions. We have already used our tools in identifying disease clusters in several contexts and these tools can be used in more meaningful, practical ways for the broader public.
